text:
<@UJG12DM1V> I love this piece! Thanks so much for sharing...going to share with a team member who’s taken on more editing work with quite a variety of contributors. 

If you read through a piece with a customer you’ve committed to working with, and it’s a nope, what’s your next step in that conversation? Even with an initial conversation, agreed upon brief and outline we’ve found some hits and misses when it comes to actually putting pen to paper.

elements.text:
I love this piece! Thanks so much for sharing...going to share with a team member who’s taken on more editing work with quite a variety of contributors. 

If you read through a piece with a customer you’ve committed to working with, and it’s a nope, what’s your next step in that conversation? Even with an initial conversation, agreed upon brief and outline we’ve found some hits and misses when it comes to actually putting pen to paper.

text: Yeah, that's tough. In this article my recommendation is to not give the yes/no until you see the crappy first draft. It's just really hard to get a sense of the writing skills without something in hand. For a more experienced writer, or just someone you've worked with before, it's smart to start with a brief and outline, but I've been in the situation you're describing too many times.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz
